item.title: iOS5 SunSpider: iPhone 4S vs iPhone 4 vs iPhone 3GS
item.description: Result table (SunSpider 0.9.1, all devices running iOS 5) Test <td> iPhone 4S </td> <td> iPhone 4 </td> <td> iPhone 3GS </td> Total <td class="positive"> 2270ms </td> <td> 3483ms </td> <td> 4903ms </td> 3D <td class="positive"> 281ms </td> <td> 486ms </td> <td> 672ms </td> Access <td class="positive"> 279ms </td></td> <td> 410ms </td> <td> 614ms </td> Bitops <td class="positive"> 177ms </td> <td> 200ms </td> <td> 270ms </td> Controlflow <td class="positive"> 20ms </td> <td> 26ms </td></td> <td> 34ms </td> Crypto <td class="positive"> 164ms </td> <td> 211ms </td> <td> 315ms </td> Date <td class="positive"> 332ms </td> <td> 528ms </td> <td> 770ms </td> Math <td class="positive"> 219ms </td> <td> 433ms </td> <td> 553ms </td> Regexp <td class="positive"> 88ms </td> <td> 117ms </td> <td> 151ms </td> String <td class="positive"> 711ms </td> <td> 1072ms </td> <td> 1525ms </td> Raw results iPhone 4S (iOS5)

item.title: iPhone 4S, iPhone 4, and iPhone 3GS photo comparison
item.description: More photos likely to come.. this is just after I unboxed my new 4S. Time to play with it a bit! iPhone 4S iPhone 4 iPhone 3GS iPhone 3GS (alternate white balance point)

item.title: Implementing iPhone's slider unlock with input type='range'
item.description: ⚠️ Warning: this is an old article and may include information that’s out of date. ⚠️ (check out the live demo) Introduction After reading “What the Heck is Shadow DOM?" I was inspired to see how far I could style the <input type="range"> element. Pretty far, as it turns out! My goal was to change the input’s default appearance: To the visual appearance of the iPhone’s unlock slider: As far as I can tell, only WebKit-based browsers and Opera have implemented input type=range.

item.title: iPhone 4 SunSpider test results (22% faster than iPhone 3GS)
JavaScript SunSpider test: iOS 3.1.3 versus iOS 4 GM
item.description: Result table Test <td> iOS 3.1.3 (3GS) </td> <td> iOS 4 GM (3GS) </td> <td> % change </td> Total <td> 15396ms </td> <td> 13787ms </td> <td class="positive"> -10.5% </td> 3D <td> 2411ms </td> <td> 1917ms </td> <td class="positive"> -20.5% </td> Access <td> 1884ms </td> <td> 1893ms </td> <td class="negative"> +0.5% </td> Bitops <td> 1044ms </td> <td> 1239ms </td> <td class="negative"> +18.

item.title: PastryKit: digging into an Apple Pie
item.description: ⚠️ Warning: this is an old article and may include information that’s out of date. ⚠️ Yesterday John Gruber wrote about Apple’s PastryKit, iPhone’s JavaScript framework that’s been discovered “in the wild” on the iPhone user guide at http://help.apple.com/iphone/3/mobile/. There’s a few ways to access the page: with an actual iPhone or iTouch by browsing with an iPhone/iTouch user agent. If you’re using Safari, enable the Developer menu in Safari>Preferences>Advanced and switching user agents by clicking on Develope>User Agent What’s all the big fuss?
